elements.content: Three novel coordination polymers, namely, {[Ni(2,2‘,3,3‘-H2tdpa)(H2O)2]·(H2O)2} n (1), [Ni3(2,2‘,3,3‘-Htdpa)2(H2O)12] n (2), and {[Ni4(2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpa)2(bpy)4(H2O)4]·(H2O)10} n (3), were prepared under hydrothermal conditions through rational control of the hydrolysis of a new flexible ligand of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda (2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda = 2,2‘,3,3‘-thiodiphthalic dianhydride; 2,2‘,3,3‘-H4tdpa = 2,2‘,3,3‘-thiodiphthalic acid) and characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, thermogravimetric analysis, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. In 1, two neighboring nickel ions are first bridged together through 3-COO- in bidentate fashion and μ 2 -H2O to form a one-dimensional (1D) Ni chain. These 1D chains are further locked with each other by 2‘-COO- in monodentate fashion to form a two-dimensional (2D) alternate square tubule sheet. For 2, Ni1 atoms are coordinated by 2,2‘-COO- in monodentate fashion to form alternate left- and right-helices, which are further bridged together by the coordination interactions between Ni2 atoms and 3-COO- to give a 2D helical coordination polymer. 3 has a three-dimensional (3D) chiral open framework with homochiral sheets and 4,4‘-bpy pillars. Thermogravimetric analysis and powder X-ray diffraction analysis show that the porous framework of 3 is stable after removal of both solvent and coordination water molecules. Both 1 and 2 show paramagnetic behaviors, while 3 displays a metamagnetic behavior.

elements.content: The construction of inorganic coordination polymeric complexes has developed rapidly in recent years, owing to their interesting molecular topologies and crystal packing motifs along with potential applications as functional materials. These metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) can be rapidly and efficiently synthesized from relatively simple subunits, where the kind of metal ions, geometry, and number of coordination sites provided by organic ligands are all important parameters for directing the self-assembly processes. The rational design and reasonable use of the characteristic ligand is very important in the construction of the desired MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The construction of inorganic coordination polymeric complexes has developed rapidly in recent years, owing to their interesting molecular topologies and crystal packing motifs along with potential applications as functional materials. These metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) can be rapidly and efficiently synthesized from relatively simple subunits, where the kind of metal ions, geometry, and number of coordination sites provided by organic ligands are all important parameters for directing the self-assembly processes. The rational design and reasonable use of the characteristic ligand is very important in the construction of the desired MOFs.

elements.content: It is well-known that a carboxylate group can bridge metal ions to give rise to a wide variety of polynuclear complexes ranging from discrete entities to three-dimensional (3D) systems. In these complexes, a carboxylate group can assume many types of bridging conformations, the most important being triatomic syn−syn, anti−anti, and syn−anti and monatomic. As expected, the magnetic properties are closely related to the bridging information adopted by the carboxylate group in these polynuclear systems. Searching for new versatile polycarboxylates ligands is very important in investigating new topologies and various functional materials.

elements.content: Recently, we introduced a versatile ligand of 2,2‘,3,3‘-odpda to construct chiral helical coordination polymers. The interesting results inspired us to investigate its analogue of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda (2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda = 2,2‘,3,3‘-thiodiphthalic dianhydride) (Scheme ) owing to the following reasions:  (1) The introduction of etheric sulfur instead of an oxygen atom may enhance conjugation of two parts of the ligand in 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda. (2) Hydrolysis of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda can produce multiple products as H3tdpa-, H2tdpa2-, Htdpa3-, and tdpa4-, with the number of potential donor oxygen atoms varying from one to eight, which are all versatile ligands for the construction of novel high-dimensional metal−organic hybrid compounds. (3) It can act not only as a hydrogen-bond acceptor but also as a hydrogen-bond donor, depending upon the number of deprotonated carboxyl groups. (4) The hindrances of the 2,2‘-, 2,3-, and 2‘,3‘-carboxylate group and the flexiblity around the etheric sulfur atom provide potentiality of the formation of a helix structure. (5) Upon coordination as a bridge, the freedom of the ligand to rotate around the etheric sulfur atom is restrained, and the ligand can be locked in a twisted chiral conformation. With the aim of understanding the coordination chemistry of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda and preparing new materials with interesting structural topologies and excellent physical properties, we recently engaged in the research of coordination polymers based on this and related ligands.

elements.content:
In this paper, we report three coordination polymers through reasonable control of the hydrolysis of this new flexible ligand of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda.

Experimental Section

2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda was synthesized according to the literature. All other starting materials were of reagent quality and were obtained from commercial sources without further purification.

{[Ni(2,2‘,3,3‘-H2 tdpa)(H 2 O) 2 ] · (H 2 O) 2 } n (1). 1 was synthesized hydrothermally in a 23-mL Teflon-lined autoclave by heating a mixture of 0.1 mmol of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda, 0.2 mM NaOH, and 0.1 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O in 10 mL of water at 120 °C for 2 days. Green block single crystals were collected in 68% yield based on nickel. Anal. found (calcd) for C16H16NiO12S:  C, 39.17 (39.11); H, 3.21 (3.28); Ni, 11.90 (11.95) %; IR (KBr, cm-1):  3449(s, br), 215(s, br), 2656(m), 1686(vs), 1593(s), 1573(s), 1558(s), 1459(m), 1438(w), 1388(s), 1302(s), 1203(w), 1174(w), 1111(m), 866(m), 836(w), 777(vs), 722(vs), 695(w), 671(w), 596(w), 478(m), 441(w).

elements.content: Physical Measurements. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The metal contents were determined by EDTA titration. The IR spectra were obtained as KBr pellets on a VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a TGA V5.1A Dupont 2100 instrument from room temperature to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in air. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a RigakuD/max-RA rotating anode X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) radiation at room temperature. The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on polycrystalline samples with a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID susceptometer. The diamagnetic corrections were evaluated from Pascal's constants for all the constituent atoms.

Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a RigakuD/max-RA rotating anode X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) radiation at room temperature. The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on polycrystalline samples with a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID susceptometer. The diamagnetic corrections were evaluated from Pascal's constants for all the constituent atoms.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallographic Studies. Single crystals of dimensions 0.32 × 0.20 × 0.15 mm for 1, 0.28 × 0.16 × 0.12 mm for 2, and 0.35 × 0.26 × 0.18 mm for 3 were used for structural determinations on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature using the ω-scan technique. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for 1−3 are listed in Table and Table S1, Supporting Information.

Syntheses. In the beginning, complexes were synthesized hydrothermally in a 23-mL Teflon-lined autoclave by heating a mixture of 0.1 mmol of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda, 0.2 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, and one drop of Et3N at 120 °C for 2 days. The results were a mixture of a small amount of green crystals of [Ni3(2,2‘,3,3‘-Htdpa)2(H2O)12] (2) and a great mass of unknown green powder. The successful isolation of 2 prompted us to extend our study to other complexes based on the other productions of the hydrolysis of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda. Thus, we strictly controlled the hydrolysis of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda through modulating the addition of alkali. As expected, either 1 or 2 can be obtained as a single phase as perfect crystals. However, we observed that the direct reaction of Ni(II) ion with 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpa4- gave a green powder. Fortunately, when the “second” ligand of 4,4‘-bpy was added to the reaction system, 3 in its crystalline form was successfully isolated in good yield. Although detailed studies are still required to better understand this phenomenon, we propose that the rate of polymerization of Ni(II) ions with 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpa4- is too fast to obtain crystalline products. In addition, the “mix-ligands” method is a new idea to construct MOFs and has aroused attractive attention in the design of open porous MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Syntheses. In the beginning, complexes were synthesized hydrothermally in a 23-mL Teflon-lined autoclave by heating a mixture of 0.1 mmol of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda, 0.2 mmol of Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O, and one drop of Et3N at 120 °C for 2 days. The results were a mixture of a small amount of green crystals of [Ni3(2,2‘,3,3‘-Htdpa)2(H2O)12] (2) and a great mass of unknown green powder. The successful isolation of 2 prompted us to extend our study to other complexes based on the other productions of the hydrolysis of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda. Thus, we strictly controlled the hydrolysis of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda through modulating the addition of alkali. As expected, either 1 or 2 can be obtained as a single phase as perfect crystals. However, we observed that the direct reaction of Ni(II) ion with 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpa4- gave a green powder. Fortunately, when the "second" ligand of 4,4‘-bpy was added to the reaction system, 3 in its crystalline form was successfully isolated in good yield. Although detailed studies are still required to better understand this phenomenon, we propose that the rate of polymerization of Ni(II) ions with 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpa4- is too fast to obtain crystalline products. In addition, the "mix-ligands" method is a new idea to construct MOFs and has aroused attractive attention in the design of open porous MOFs.

elements.content: Crystal Structures. {[Ni(2,2‘,3,3‘-H 2 tdpa)(H 2 O) 2 ] · (H 2 O) 2 } n (1). The asymmetric unit contains one Ni(II) ion, one 2,2‘,3,3‘-H2tdpa2- anion, two coordinated, and two solvated water molecules (Figure S1, Supporting Information). As to 2,2‘,3,3‘-H2tdpa2-, the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings is 80.8°, the 2- and 2‘-carboxylate groups are almost perpendicular to the plane of corresponding linking phenyl rings with the dihedral angle between them being 98.1° and 98.0°, respectively. 3- and 3‘-carboxylate groups have 18.5° and 20.1° dihedral angles, respectively, with the plane of corresponding linking phenyl rings.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , each Ni(II) atom is in a octahedral geometry by coordinating to one oxygen atom (O1) of 3-COO-, one oxygen atom (O2B) of 3-COO- from neighboring molecular, one oxygen atom (O6C) of 2‘-COO- from another neighboring molecular, one oxygen atom (O9) from water molecules, and two bridged O10 and O10B oxygen atoms. The Ni−O bonds range between 2.037(3) and 2.143(3) Å. Two neighboring nickel ions are first bridged together through 3-COO- in bidentate fashion and μ 2 -H2O to form a one-dimensional (1D) Ni chain (Figure ). These 1D chains are further locked to each other by 2‘-COO- in monodentate fashion to form a two-dimensional (2D) square tubule sheet (Figures and ). The two remaining 2- and 3‘-COOH groups are hydrogen bonded to other adjacent carboxylate groups and water molecules. In addition, there are some other hydrogen bonds between 2‘-COO- group and water molecules (Table S2, Supporting Information). Through the interlayer hydrogen bonds interactions, 1 gives a 3D supramolecular structure (Figure S2, Supporting Information).

elements.content: [Ni 3 (2,2‘,3,3‘-Htdpa) 2 (H 2 O) 12 ] (2). Complex 2 features a helical coordination architecture, in which Ni1 ions are integrated by a 2,2‘3,3‘-Htdpa3- ligand into helical chains with both left- and right-handed chirality; these helices are further united together by Ni2 ions into a 2D helical MOF by the coordination interaction between Ni2 ions and 3-COO-. As shown in Figure , Ni1 ion is in an octahedral geometry by coordinating to one oxygen atom (O5) of 2-COO-, one oxygen atom (O4B) of 2‘-COO- from neighboring ligands, and four oxygen atoms (O9, O10, O11, O12) from water molecules. As to 2,2‘,3,3‘-Htdpa3- ligands, the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings is 91.0°, and the 2- and 2‘-carboxylate groups are almost perpendicular to the plane of the corresponding linking phenyl rings with the dihedral angle between them being 87.7° and 79.0°, respectively. 3- and 3‘-carboxylate groups have 6.3° and 21.7° dihedral angles, respectively, with the plane of the corresponding linking phenyl rings. When 2- and 2‘-carboxylate groups both participate in coordination with Ni(II) ions, there must be some hindrance between them. The combination of these twists with the nonlinear flexibility around the S1 atom results in the formation of Ni1−Htdpa3- helical chains (Figure a,b). Ni2 ion also is in an octahedral geometry by coordinating to two oxygen atoms (O2, O2A) of two 3-COO- groups from two neighboring 2,2‘,3,3‘-Htdpa3- ligands, four oxygen atoms (O13, O13A, O14, O14A) from two pairs of symmetry-related water molecules (symmetry code −x + 1, −y + 1, −z + 1). The most interesting characteristic of 2 is that the Ni1−Htdpa3- helical chains are all connected together by the Ni2 atoms through coordinating to the 3-COO- groups to give a 2D helical coordination polymer with alternative left- and right-handed charity (Figure c). The remaining 3‘-COOH groups are hydrogen bonded to O10 (O7−O10 = 2.729 Å) and O3 atoms of 2-COO- from other molecules (O8−O3 = 2.600 Å; symmetry code:  x + 1/2, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2). There are also some other hydrogen bonds in this system (Table S3, Supporting Information). The distance of two phenyl rings in adjacent layers is about 3.6 Å, which indicates weak π−π stacking interactions occur between them. Thus, the 2D helical framework is further united together through both hydrogen bonds and π−π stacking interactions to give a 3D supramolecular structure (Figure S3, Supporting Information).

elements.content: {[Ni 4 (2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpa)(bpy) 4 (H 2 O) 4 ] · (H 2 O) 10 } (3). Compound 3 crystallizes in space group C2 and is a 3D chiral porous coordination polymer, in which homochiral Ni(II)-tdpa4- chains are united together by sulfur atoms of tdpa ligands and the 3- and 3‘-COO- in bidentate fashion to form 2D polar and chiral planes; these planes are further supported by 4,4‘-bpy to give a 3D network. The crystal structure of 3 reveals that each metal atom is six-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpa4- [Ni1−O1, 2.069 (3) Å; Ni1−O3, 2.077(4) Å; Ni1−O4A, 2.058(3) Å], two nitrogen atoms from 4,4‘-bpy [Ni1−N1, 2.096(4) Å; Ni1−N2, 2.118(4) Å], and one oxygen atom from the coordinated water molecular [Ni1−O5, 2.055(3) Å] in an octahedron geometry (Figure ). The Ni(II) ions are linked by syn−anti 3- or 3‘-COO- groups to form a infinite chiral helical chain (Figure a,b), in which all geometries of Ni(II) ions have the same chirality. Upon coordination as a bridge, the freedom of the ligand to rotate around the etheric sulfur atom is restrained, and the ligand can be locked in a twisted chiral conformation. Obviously, the twist of the ligand plays a crucial role in the initial generation of molecular chirality. The twisted 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpa ligand equipped with four coordination sites is chirally discriminative and requires that the four metal chromophores exhibit the same absolute configuration in the unit. The homochirality between chains is achieved via the interunit 3- and 3‘-COO- groups in bidentate fashion in the gauche conformation (Figure c,d). Swallow-like chiral open channels of approximately 8 × 5 Å2 were generated along the c axis.

elements.content: Another outstanding feature is that these 2D chiral layers can be supported by the second rigid ligand to give a 3D chiral porous framework with channels of approximate dimensions of 9.5 × 11.3 Å2, estimated using the Ni−Ni separations along the b axis as shown in Figure . Solvent water molecules occupy the holes through hydrogen bonds (Table S4, Supporting Information). Void volume for 3 is 31% as calculated by PLATON from its crystal structure (van der Waals radii are taken into account). On the basis of our understanding of chiral porous MOFs, 2 is a rare example that is constructed from mix-ligand methods.

elements.content: According to the above structural description of our example compounds, 2,2‘,3,3‘-H2tdpa2-, 2,2‘,3,3‘-Htdpa3-, 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpa4- ligands exhibit three distinct kinds of bridging modes as shown in Scheme . In complex 1, the 2,2‘,3,3‘-H2tdpa2- ligand bridges one kind of Ni(II) ion through one 3-COO- in bidentate fashion and one 2‘-COO- in monodentate fashion. 2- and 3‘-COOH groups remain protonated. In complex 2, 2,2‘,3,3‘-Htdpa3- bridges two kind of Ni(II) ions:  twisted 2- and 2‘-COO- groups bridge the Ni1 ions to form Ni1-helices, while the 3-COO- groups act as additional coordination sites for Ni1-helices to coordinate to Ni2 ions to form a 2D helical MOF. The 3‘-carboxylate groups remain protonated. In 3, the twisted 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpa4- ligand coordinates to Ni(II) ions through 2- and 2‘-carboxylate in monodentate fashion and 3- and 3‘-carboxylate in bidentate fashion to give a 2D chiral layer.

In complex 1, the 2,2‘,3,3‘-H2tdpa2- ligand bridges one kind of Ni(II) ion through one 3-COO- in bidentate fashion and one 2‘-COO- in monodentate fashion. 2- and 3‘-COOH groups remain protonated. In complex 2, 2,2‘,3,3‘-Htdpa3- bridges two kind of Ni(II) ions: twisted 2- and 2‘-COO- groups bridge the Ni1 ions to form Ni1-helices, while the 3-COO- groups act as additional coordination sites for Ni1-helices to coordinate to Ni2 ions to form a 2D helical MOF. The 3‘-carboxylate groups remain protonated. In 3, the twisted 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpa4- ligand coordinates to Ni(II) ions through 2- and 2‘-carboxylate in monodentate fashion and 3- and 3‘-carboxylate in bidentate fashion to give a 2D chiral layer.

elements.content: Thermal Analyses and PXRD Studies. For 1, the weight loss of 15.03% (calcd. 14.68%) below 210 °C corresponds to the loss of two solvent and two coordinated water molecules per formula. For 2, the weight loss of 19.72% (calcd. 19.46%) below 170 °C is attributed to the release of 12 coordinated water molecules per formula. For 3, the weight loss of 14.35% (calcd. 13.80%) below 150 °C is the loss of four coordinated and 10 solvent water molecules per formula (Figure S4, Supporting Information, shows the TG curves for 1−3).

elements.content: The existence of guest molecules in the porous framework of 3 inspired us to investigate the thermal stability of the framework. To further test the stability of the porous framework, we examined the powder samples by X-ray diffraction analysis. Both solvent and coordination water molecules were removed by heating 3 at 150 °C for 2 h. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of as-synthesized 3 and dehydrated samples are nearly identical (Figure ), which indicates that the porous framework can stably exist even at the loss of both the guest and the coordination water molecules.

elements.content: Magnetic Properties. The temperature dependencies of the magnetic susceptibilities for 1 and 3 were measured at a temperature of 1.8−300 K at 2 kOe. Since there are large separations for both Ni(1)···Ni(1) (ca. 5.076 Å and pass through nine bridging atoms) and Ni(1)···Ni(2) (ca. 5.249 Å and pass through six bridging atoms), it is imaginable that magnetic interactions between Ni2+ ions are very weak. Therefore, the magnetic susceptibilities for 2 were not measured.

Since there are large separations for both Ni(1)⋅⋅⋅Ni(1) (ca. 5.076 Å and pass through nine bridging atoms) and Ni(1)⋅⋅⋅Ni(2) (ca. 5.249 Å and pass through six bridging atoms), it is imaginable that magnetic interactions between Ni2+ ions are very weak. Therefore, the magnetic susceptibilities for 2 were not measured.

elements.content: The global feature of the χT vs T curve for 1 is characteristic of antiferromagnetic interactions (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The value of χT at 300 K is 1.168 emu K mol-1 per nickel(II). On decreasing of the temperature, the χT value decreases slowly to 1.111 emu K mol-1 at 120 K, and then it decreases rapidly to 0.079 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K. The plots of χT vs T in the range of 1.8−300 K obey the Curie−Weiss law with C = 1.323 emu K mol-1, g = 2.26 and a negative Weiss constant θ = −25.723 K for 1. These observations suggest overall antiferromagnetic interactions between nickel ions in 1.

The value of χT at 300 K is 1.168 emu K mol-1 per nickel(II). On decreasing of the temperature, the χT value decreases slowly to 1.111 emu K mol-1 at 120 K, and then it decreases rapidly to 0.079 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K. The plots of χT vs T in the range of 1.8-300 K obey the Curie-Weiss law with C = 1.323 emu K mol-1, g = 2.26 and a negative Weiss constant θ = -25.723 K for 1. elements.content: Figure shows the magnetic behavior of 3 in the form of a χm T vs T plot. At 300 K, χm T is 1.212 emu K mol-1 per nickel(II) and remains nearly constant until 60 K; below this temperature, the χm T value increases continuously to a maximum of 1.849 emu K mol-1, indicating the overall ferromagnetic coupling in 3. Upon further cooling below 4.0 K, the χm T values decrease to 0.943 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K, which could be due to the antiferromagnetic interactions through 4,4‘-bpy. The χm -1 vs T curve is almost linear in the whole temperature range (Figure S6, Supporting Information). The data were therefore analyzed by the Curie−Weiss law, which led to the parameters C = 1.120 emu K mol-1 and θ = 0.718 K, corresponding to the parameter g = 2.190. The small positive θ value indicates the weak dominant ferromagnetic interactions in 3. The χm−T plot shows a cusp around 2.2 K at a field lower than 2 kOe, which disappears at high field (Figure ). This indicates an antiferromagnetic (AF) ground state, and a transition from AF to ferromagnetic state occurs when the applied field is large enough over 2 kOe. The critical field is approximately 2 kOe, where a maximum ∂M/∂H value is reached.

elements.content: The construction of helical coordination polymers has aroused a great deal of attention owing to the wide appearance of helical structures in, for example, proteins, collagens, quartz, single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs), and many more natural or artificial fiber-type derivatives.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The construction of helical coordination polymers has aroused a great deal of attention owing to the wide appearance of helical structures in, for example, proteins, collagens, quartz, single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs), and many more natural or artificial fiber-type derivatives.

elements.content: We have recently engaged in the research of helical coordination polymers based on the 2,2‘,3‘3‘-tdpda ligand and its isomers owing to their charming characteristics. In this paper, we obtained three novel coordination polymers through rational control of the hydrolysis of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda under hydrothermal conditions. Among them, 2 is a 2D helical MOF with both right and left helical chains while 3 is a 3D chiral porous MOF with homochiral helices. The results confirm that 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpa is a promising ligand for constructing novel MOFs with helical substructures. In addition, 3 has a permanent porous MOF subject to the loss of both guest and coordination water molecules and shows a metamagnetic behavior. More efforts will focus on the construction of novel coordination polymers by reacting this ligand and its isomers with other metal ions.

cln_elements.content:
In this paper, we report three coordination polymers through reasonable control of the hydrolysis of this new flexible ligand of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda.

Experimental Section

2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda was synthesized according to the literature. All other starting materials were of reagent quality and were obtained from commercial sources without further purification.

{[Ni(2,2‘,3,3‘-H2 tdpa)(H 2 O) 2 ] · (H 2 O) 2 } n (1). 1 was synthesized hydrothermally in a 23-mL Teflon-lined autoclave by heating a mixture of 0.1 mmol of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda, 0.2 mM NaOH, and 0.1 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O in 10 mL of water at 120 °C for 2 days. Green block single crystals were collected in 68% yield based on nickel. Anal. found (calcd) for C16H16NiO12S:  C, 39.17 (39.11); H, 3.21 (3.28); Ni, 11.90 (11.95) %; IR (KBr, cm-1):  3449(s, br), 215(s, br), 2656(m), 1686(vs), 1593(s), 1573(s), 1558(s), 1459(m), 1438(w), 1388(s), 1302(s), 1203(w), 1174(w), 1111(m), 866(m), 836(w), 777(vs), 722(vs), 695(w), 671(w), 596(w), 478(m), 441(w).

[Ni 3 (2,2 ‘ ,3,3 ‘ -Htdpa) 2 (H 2 O) 12 ] n (2). 2 was synthesized hydrothermally in a 23-mL Teflon-lined autoclave by heating a mixture of 0.1 mmol of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda, 0.3 mM NaOH, and 0.15 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O in 10 mL of water at 120 °C for 2 days. Green needle single crystals were collected in 72% yield based on nickel. Anal. found (calcd) for C32H38Ni3O28S2:  C, 34.67 (34.60); H, 3.51 (3.45); Ni, 15.87 (15.85) %; IR (KBr, cm-1):  3588(s), 3381(s, br), 3109(s, br), 1658(vs), 1562(s), 1456(m), 1386(s), 1257(s), 1154(w), 1066(w), 775(m), 759(w), 726(vs), 589(m), 648(w), 504(w), 473(w).

{[Ni 4 (2,2 ‘ ,3,3 ‘ -tdpa) 2 (bpy) 4 (H 2 O) 4 ]·(H 2 O) 10 } n (3). 3 was synthesized hydrothermally in a 23-mL Teflon-lined autoclave by heating a mixture of 0.1 mmol of 2,2‘,3,3‘-tdpda, 0.4 mM NaOH, 0.2 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, and 0.2 mmol of 4,4‘-bpy in 10 mL of water at 120 °C for 2 days. cln_elements.content:
Another outstanding feature is that these 2D chiral layers can be supported by the second rigid ligand to give a 3D chiral porous framework with channels of approximate dimensions of 9.5 × 11.3 Å2, estimated using the Ni−Ni separations along the b axis as shown in Figure . Solvent water molecules occupy the holes through hydrogen bonds (Table S4, Supporting Information). Void volume for 3 is 31% as calculated by PLATON from its crystal structure (van der Waals radii are taken into account). On the basis of our understanding of chiral porous MOFs, 2 is a rare example that is constructed from mix-ligand methods.

Thermal Analyses and PXRD Studies. For 1, the weight loss of 15.03% (calcd. 14.68%) below 210 °C corresponds to the loss of two solvent and two coordinated water molecules per formula. For 2, the weight loss of 19.72% (calcd. 19.46%) below 170 °C is attributed to the release of 12 coordinated water molecules per formula. For 3, the weight loss of 14.35% (calcd. 13.80%) below 150 °C is the loss of four coordinated and 10 solvent water molecules per formula (Figure S4, Supporting Information, shows the TG curves for 1−3).

The global feature of the χT vs T curve for 1 is characteristic of antiferromagnetic interactions (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The value of χT at 300 K is 1.168 emu K mol-1 per nickel(II). On decreasing of the temperature, the χT value decreases slowly to 1.111 emu K mol-1 at 120 K, and then it decreases rapidly to 0.079 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K. The plots of χT vs T in the range of 1.8−300 K obey the Curie−Weiss law with C = 1.323 emu K mol-1, g = 2.26 and a negative Weiss constant θ = −25.723 K for 1. These observations suggest overall antiferromagnetic interactions between nickel ions in 1.

Figure shows the magnetic behavior of 3 in the form of a χm T vs T plot. At 300 K, χm T is 1.212 emu K mol-1 per nickel(II) and remains nearly constant until 60 K; below this temperature, the χm T value increases continuously to a maximum of 1.849 emu K mol-1, indicating the overall ferromagnetic coupling in 3. Upon further cooling below 4.0 K, the χm T values decrease to 0.943 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K, which could be due to the antiferromagnetic interactions through 4,4‘-bpy. The χm -1 vs T curve is almost linear in the whole temperature range (Figure S6, Supporting Information). The data were therefore analyzed by the Curie−Weiss law, which led to the parameters C = 1.120 emu K mol-1 and θ = 0.718 K, corresponding to the parameter g = 2.190. The small positive θ value indicates the weak dominant ferromagnetic interactions in 3. The χm−T plot shows a cusp around 2.2 K at a field lower than 2 kOe, which disappears at high field (Figure ). This indicates an antiferromagnetic (AF) ground state, and a transition from AF to ferromagnetic state occurs when the applied field is large enough over 2 kOe. The critical field is approximately 2 kOe, where a maximum ∂M/∂H value is reached.
